arm_group.description: Thyroid cancer group: patients with differentiated or dedifferentiated thyroid cancer Healty: control group

brief_summary.textblock:
In clinical practise patients with negative radioiodine scan with positive tyhroglobulin is
      considered as radioiodine resistant or in another words in the process of dedifferentiation.
      The aim of the present study was to search a simple blood test that could lead to early
      identification of patients with dedifferentiation. In this respect, we investigate whether
      the serum level of anti-p53 antibody has the diagnostic value in the follow-up of patients
      with high levels of thyroglobulin (tg) and  negative I-131 scan.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Patients who were diagnosed with DTC

          -  Treated with total and/or near-total thyroidectomy

          -  Referred for I-131 ablation therapy or low dose I-131 whole body scan (WBS)

          -  Between December 2010 and January 2013.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Dose 131-I given in another hospital

          -  Radioiodine treatment more than one year after thyroidectomy.

study_pop.textblock:
A total of 171 patients with an age range of 16-80 yrs (mean: 47.7±13.5 yrs) and a total
        of 28 healthy subjects with an age range of 18-52 yrs (mean: 36.0±9.8 yrs) were included
        in this study.

facility.name: Cumhuriyet University, School of Medicine, Dept. of Nuclear Medicine

clinical_study.official_title: P53 Antibody; Is it an Indicator of Dedifferentiated Thyroid Cancer?

primary_outcome.measure: There was not any risk for patients.
primary_outcome.time_frame: with in the first 8-10 months after surgery

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case Control, Time Perspective: Prospective
